item.title: Islamic State Steps Up Attacks on Nigerian Military Bases
item.description: Islamist militants have ramped up an insurgency in northeastern Nigeria and attacked dozens of fortified army bases since the start of the year, setting back President Bola Tinubu’s efforts to restore security in Africa’s most-populous nation.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Former Boko Haram and Iswap members who attended a rehabilitation program in Maiduguri, Nigeria, in 2023.

item.title: South Korea Votes for New Leader to Heal Nation, Spur Growth
item.description: South Koreans headed to the polls Tuesday to elect a new president after an attempt to impose martial law at the end of last year triggered its worst constitutional crisis in decades.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: A voter casts their ballot at a polling station in Incheon, South Korea. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Cuts Threaten South Africa’s HIV Success
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Patients in Johannesburg waiting for the Witkoppen Clinic to open at 6 a.m. Photographer: Marc Shoul for Bloomberg Businessweek

item.title: Cuts to US Aid Imperil the World’s Largest HIV Treatment Program
item.description: In South Africa, clinics serving marginalized groups—migrants, gay men and sex workers—are shutting down as funds dry up.
item.dc:creator: Janice Kew, Antony Sguazzin

media:content.media:description: Patients begin lining up outside the Witkoppen Clinic in Johannesburg before dawn.

item.title: South Korea Votes for New President After Months of Political Chaos

media:content.media:description: A voter casts their ballot at a polling station during the presidential election in Seoul, on June 3.

item.title: BOJ’s Ueda Hints at Likelihood of Continuing to Cut Bond Buys
item.description: Governor Kazuo Ueda hinted at the likelihood that the Bank of Japan continues to slow the pace of government bond purchases next fiscal year and stressed the bank’s expectation for economic forces to continue moving inflation toward its target.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Kazuo Ueda Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Mongolia’s Main Party to Form New Government After PM Ousted
item.description: Mongolia’s biggest political party will form a new government after lawmakers rejected a confidence vote, ousting Prime Minister Oyun-Erdene Luvsannamsrai after weeks of protests and exacerbating uncertainty for the nation’s economy as it struggles with China’s weakening demand for raw materials.
item.dc:creator: Terrence Matthew Edwards

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Luvsannamsrain Oyun-Erdene hugs members of parliaments after a vote in Ulaanbaatar on June 3, 2025. Mongolian Prime Minister Luvsannamsrain Oyun-Erdene resigned on June 3, a parliamentary statement said, after losing a confidence vote among lawmakers. The secret ballot followed days of protests in the capital Ulaanbaatar against alleged corruption. Oyun-Erdene will remain as caretaker prime minister until his successor is appointed within 30 days, the statement said. (Photo by Byambasuren BYAMBA-OCHIR / AFP) (Photo by BYAMBASUREN BYAMBA-OCHIR/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Dutch Government Falls After Far-Right Party Quits Coalition
item.description: Far-right lawmaker Geert Wilders pulled his Freedom Party out of the Netherlands’ ruling coalition, collapsing the government and likely triggering a snap election.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Freedom Party leader Geert Wilders arrives for coalition talks in The Hague on June 3. Photographer: Robin Van Lonkhuijsen/Getty Images

item.title: Poland’s Tusk Calls Confidence Vote as Coalition Squabbles
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk will seek a vote of confidence to shore up support for his government after the defeat of a political ally in Sunday’s presidential election stoked tension in the ruling coalition.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Bujnicki, Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: TIRANA, ALBANIA - MAY 16: (L-R) Poland's Prime Minister Donald Tusk talks to the press after their meeting on May 16, 2025 in Tirana, Albania. The EPC brings together heads of state and government from the 27 European Union countries and 20 others. The items on today's agenda are security and democratic resilience, competitiveness and economic security, and mobility challenges and youth empowerment. (Photo by Leon Neal - Pool /Getty Images)

item.title: Romania to Win Reprieve From EU in Struggle to Contain Deficit
item.description: The European Union is likely to offer the Romanian government a reprieve to introduce measures aimed at paring its ballooning budget deficit before moving to potential punitive action against the Black Sea nation.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Romanian President Nicusor Dan

item.title: Chinese Firms Warn EU Procurement Curb Could Hurt Trade Ties
item.description: A Chinese business lobby group warned that EU actions to curb access of the country’s medical device makers to government contracts in the bloc will hurt trade ties.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: A worker checks parts at a factory which produces medical endoscope lenses in Hangzhou, in China's eastern Zhejiang province on October 31, 2024. China's manufacturing output expanded this month for the first time since April, official data showed on October 31, rare good news for leaders struggling to boost activity in the world's second-largest economy. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT (Photo by STR/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: STR/AFP

item.title: Lutnick Sees US-India Trade Deal in ‘Not-Too-Distant Future’
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said he’s “very optimistic” about prospects for a trade deal between the US and India, suggesting an agreement could come before a July deadline for higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick Photographer: Bonnie Cash/UPI/Bloomberg

item.title: Swiss Inflation Turns Negative for First Time in Four Years
item.description: The inflation rate in Switzerland turned negative for the first time since early 2021, adding to pressure on policymakers to lower borrowing costs later this month.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

item.title: Dutch Parties Hold Emergency Talks to Avoid Government Collapse
item.description: The ruling coalition in the Netherlands will hold a second day of emergency meetings Tuesday in a bid to avoid a government collapse over the country’s migration policy.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Freedom Party leader Geert Wilders arrives for coalition talks in The Hague on June 3. Photographer: Robin Van Lonkhuijsen/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: UK Threatens to Sue Roman Abramovich Over Chelsea Sale Proceeds
item.description: The UK government said it may take billionaire Russian businessman Roman Abramovich to court in order to release £2.34 billion ($3.2 billion) from the proceeds of his sale of Chelsea football club for humanitarian purposes in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: Roman Abramovich Photographer: Clive Mason/Getty Images

item.title: Starmer Torn Between Trump and Labour on UK Defense Overhaul
item.description: Keir Starmer’s revamp of defense policy intended to show both Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin that Britain is serious about maintaining its role as a key power in Europe and NATO.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, left, and US President Donald Trump shake hands during a news conference in the East Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Feb. 27, 2025. The trip is seen as an opportunity for Starmer to prove himself as a global leader, defend democratic values, and make Britain stronger at home, while also navigating the complexities of dealing with Trump.

item.title: Trump’s Dealmaking Style Won’t Sway Xi, Ex-White House Aide Says
item.description: A potential trade deal between the world’s top two economies hinges on Donald Trump and Xi Jinping overcoming core differences in their negotiation styles, former acting White House Chief of Staff Mick Mulvaney said.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel’s Gaza Attacks Spur European Leaders to Criticize Netanyahu
item.description: Some of Israel’s most loyal supporters in Europe are increasingly speaking out against the war in Gaza, with several nations, including Germany, considering curbs on trade and arms sales.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: A man looks for survivors following an Israeli strike in the northern Gaza Strip on June 2.

item.title: Trump Says US Won’t Agree to Any Uranium Enrichment by Iran
item.description: The US won’t allow any uranium enrichment as part of a potential nuclear deal with Iran, President Donald Trump said.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: An Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) speed boat is sailing along the Persian Gulf during the IRGC marine parade, which is commemorating the Persian Gulf National Day, near the Bushehr nuclear power plant in the seaport city of Bushehr, Bushehr province, in the south of Iran, on April 29, 2024. The Persian Gulf National Day, celebrated on the 10th of Ordibehesht in the Iranian calendar, usually falls in late April or early May and commemorates the expulsion of the Portuguese from the Strait of Hormuz and the Persian Gulf in 1622 by the Safavid forces led by Imam Quli Khan under the command of Shah Abbas I. (Photo by Morteza Nikoubazl/NurPhoto via Getty Images)

item.title: How Ukraine’s Drone Arsenal Shocked Russia and Changed Modern Warfare
item.description: Costing as little as $400 apiece, Kyiv’s flying machines are successfully neutralizing sophisticated Russian equipment worth thousands of times more.
item.dc:creator: Aliaksandr Kudrytski, Jake Rudnitsky, Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: Sea Baby drone Illustrator: Chris Philpot

item.title: UK Eyes Greater Nuclear Role in Europe Amid Doubts About US
item.description: The UK envisages taking an enhanced role in NATO’s nuclear deterrence amid doubts surrounding the US commitment to the alliance, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer pledges to make Britain “war-ready” to counter Russian aggression in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: UK prime minister Keir Starmer has vowed to make Britain war-ready.

item.title: Macron and Meloni Aim to Reconcile as Europe Seeks United Front
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron and Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni will look to patch up difficult relations during a bilateral meeting in Rome on Tuesday, as Europe grapples with the seismic geopolitical shifts caused by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini, Ania Nussbaum

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, left, and Giorgia Meloni in March. Photographer: Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg

item.title: Prabowo Slams Corrupt Indonesian Officials, Warns Foreign NGOs
item.description: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto used a national holiday address to deliver a sharp warning to the country’s political elite, urging underperforming public officials to step down or face removal.
item.dc:creator: Chandra Asmara

media:content.media:description: Prabowo Subianto speaks during the commemoration of Pancasila Day on June 2. Photographer: Yasuyoshi Chiba/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Media Groups Probed by FTC Over Allegedly Coordinating Boycotts
item.description: The US Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether more than a dozen media and advertising groups have illegally colluded to boycott online content alleged to be hateful, false or misleading, according to people familiar with the matter and a document seen by Bloomberg News.
item.dc:creator: Josh Sisco, Kurt Wagner

media:content.media:description: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The Trump administration dismissed two Democrats on the US Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday, in the latest move by the White House to assert control over US agencies.

item.title: Trump Presses Reluctant GOP Senators to Embrace House Tax Bill
item.description: President Donald Trump worked the phones Monday and took to social media to try to sway Republican holdouts on his multi-trillion dollar tax bill, encountering conflicting demands from GOP senators even as he urged them to move swiftly.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Josh Hawley on June 2.

item.title: Carney Open to New Canada Oil Pipeline Tied to Carbon Capture
item.description: Mark Carney said he sees opportunity for Canada to build a new pipeline to ship more oil to foreign markets, if it’s tied to billions in green investments to reduce the industry’s environmental footprint.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: The Port of Prince Rupert in Prince Rupert, British Columbia. One project being pitched by premiers is an economic corridor running from the western port to Churchill, Manitoba.

item.title: Doritos, M&Ms Could Be Forced to Include Warning Labels in Texas
item.description: A Texas bill on the verge of becoming law would require labels on packaged food from Skittles to Mountain Dew that warn about ingredients “not recommended for human consumption” by other countries.
item.dc:creator: Will Kubzansky, Rachel Cohrs Zhang

item.title: Korean Air Chairman Calls for Political Stability, Tariff Cuts
item.description: South Korea’s next government should prioritize making a trade deal with Washington that shields the aviation industry from tariffs, the head of the country’s largest airline said.
item.dc:creator: Danny Lee, Guy Johnson

media:content.media:description: Cho Won-Tae Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

item.title: Senate Begins Putting Its Stamp on Giant Trump Tax, Debt Limit Bill
item.description: Significant changes are in store for President Donald Trump’s signature $3.9 trillion tax-cut bill as the Senate begins closed-door talks this week on legislation that squeaked through the House by a single vote.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Senator Mike Crapo in Washington. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Federal Retirement Process Goes Digital, Targeting Paper Pileup
item.description: The federal personnel agency has launched an online system for processing retirement applications, ending a paper-based method that had remained largely unchanged for decades.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Vehicles drive past the Theodore Roosevelt Building, headquarters of the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM), in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Friday, June 5, 2015. The disclosure by U.S. officials that Chinese hackers stole records of as many as 4 million government workers is now being linked to the thefts of personal information from health-care companies. The hackers, thought to have links to the Chinese government, got into the OPM computer system late last year, according to one U.S. official.
